ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned SO MUCH about the technical and policy aspects of the cyber realms. Out of all the courses I have taken at Yale, this is the one I feel I have the most knowledge leaving as compared to coming in.
Great survey of current issues in cyberspace. Learned about the US cyber response, cybersecurity, and public-private cyber endeavors.
I think this course helped me learn how to discuss cybersecurity.

This course gave me a greater understanding of how cybersecurity and cyberintelligence are ever-growing fields. I learned about what Cyberwar is, and what the global threats are. I also learned about solutions to cyberwarfare and ways in which cyberwarfare is currently evolving.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: clearly organized syllabus; opportunities to apply knowledge in project-based settings; wonderful guest speakers and opportunities to meet with practitioners of the field; clear feed back

Weaknesses: Truly, none.
Yale Cyber Forum was awesome. Being in the class made me more engaged in the Forum and vice versa.
Everything was great. Professor Wittenstein is awesome and participation in the Yale Cyber Leadership Forum was a highlight of the course.
I thought the discussions were very intriguing, but I think there could be a greater focus on technical knowledge.

The course is really well taught and Prof. Wittenstein is great at facilitating discussions on relevant topics. The themes of the class were very relevant to what's happening in the world right now, while also providing a good amount of history and context. Taking a class with law school and other grad school students was a unique learning experience! The courseload wasn't too high which helped me devote a lot of time to preparing for the class and participating in it. The guest speakers were super insightful, and Prof. Wittenstein encouraged a critical, impartial analysis of all the topics we covered.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: ABSOLUTELY. Anyone interested in cyber  which should be everyone given its increasing relevance in today's world  would benefit from taking this class. It has a reasonable workload, interesting readings, and is taught by a thoughtful professor who takes the time to engage with his students. If you're a technical person, it will give you a foundation in the policy side of cyber; if you're a policy person, it will brief you on the technical. Further, the mix of undergrads and graduate/professional school students gives the class a depth of perspective. In my view, a must take class.

100%. The class content is timely and very interesting and assignments, especially the simulation, was a lot of fun. The course also grants you access to the Yale Cyber Leadership Forum which is an amazing opportunity to meet academics and practitioners in the cyber field. Would highly recommend anyone interested in cyber issues take this course.
Yes! I thought the events were very helpful

Yes I would! It is very well taught and a unique experience in terms of the diversity of backgrounds of the students in the class. Prof. Wittenstein is a great professor and has a lot of experience that one can learn from.
YES! Best class I've taken at Yale. There are so many ways outside of the classroom (talks, visiting professionals, events, office hours) to engage in the material.

I would recommend this course to others. Professor Wittenstein is a fantastic professor that is dedicated to helping his students learn and develop. This course is designed to introduce computer science concepts to law students and law concepts to computer scientists. This course does a fantastic job of performing these tasks.
